'''Turuhalmë''', or the '''Logdrawing''', was an [[Elves|Elvish]] holiday of [[Yule]],<ref name=app /> centered on the bringing in of wood to [[Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva]] to feed the [[Tale-fire]], according to the earliest version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref>{{LT1|Index}}, entry "Turuhalmë"</ref>

As described by [[Lindo]] in the [[Cottage of Lost Play]], it was a day of sports in the snow, and logs were drawn from the woods, followed by singing and drinking, after which tales were told around the [[Tale-fire]]. During this night, [[Eriol]] heard the tale of the [[Gilfanon's Tale: The Travail of the Noldoli and the Coming of Mankind|Travail of the Noldoli]] from [[Ailios]].<ref>{{LT1|X}}, pp. 229-30. Cf. also ''[[The Book of Lost Tales Part Two]]'', p. 69</ref>

== Etymology ==
''Turuhalmë'' is [[Qenya]] for "Logdrawing", from ''[[turu]]'' ("wood; mainly firewood") + ''halm'' ("drawing"). The [[Gnomish]] cognates, '''''Duruchalmo'''''('''''s''''') and '''''Halm na-dhuruthon''''', were glossed as "[[Yule]]".<ref name=app>{{LT1|Appendix}}, entry "Turuhalmë"</ref> In the ''[[Gnomish Lexicon]]'', it is said that the last term referred to the morning following the Yule night: ''Durufui'' or ''Tonfui''.<ref>{{PE|11}}, p. 47</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
Tolkien also considered the terms ''Halmadhurwion'' and ''Duruchalm'' in a note, but struck out ''Duruchalm''.<ref>{{LT1|Xn}}, p. 244, note 1</ref>
